Package visualisingCellularAutomata

Class LifePanel

java.lang.Object
java.awt.Component
java.awt.Container
javax.swing.JComponent
javax.swing.JPanel
visualisingCellularAutomata.LifePanel
All Implemented Interfaces:
java.awt.event.ActionListener, java.awt.event.MouseListener, java.awt.event.MouseMotionListener, java.awt.image.ImageObserver, java.awt.MenuContainer, java.io.Serializable, java.util.EventListener, javax.accessibility.Accessible
public class LifePanel
extends javax.swing.JPanel
implements java.awt.event.ActionListener, java.awt.event.MouseListener, java.awt.event.MouseMotionListener
This is what pixels appear on.

    • lifeArray

      Cell[][] lifeArray
      Stores the grid of cells. This grid is displayed graphically.

      Uses lifeArray to generate the next generation of cells, which are stored in this array.

      Default colours for the grid and cells to be drawn (Grey and White). Can't be changed by the user (in this version).

      public static javax.swing.Timer timer
      Default update delay = 75ms.

    • saveToLoad

      public static java.lang.String saveToLoad
      This string determines which file to load. Default value does not matter.

    • initialLoad

      public static java.lang.String initialLoad
      An empty string indicates to randomly load. Otherwise, load the save specified by the string. Effectively controlled by InitialPopup class, and is only ever set once (when the program starts).
      See Also:
      InitialPopup

    • stampToUse

      public static int stampToUse
      Default stamp is no stamp at all, indicated by 0.

      public static int drawState
      Default draw state of 0 is to draw live cells.

      Determines if the simulation should be paused or not.

      public static boolean singleStepFlag
      Signals to generate the next generation and immediately pause.

      public static boolean randomState
      Signals to randomly set the states of all cells in the simulation.

    • birthSet

      public static java.util.Set<java.lang.Integer> birthSet
      This stores the rules that result in a dead cell becoming alive. Default is Conway's Game of Life.

    • survivalSet

      public static java.util.Set<java.lang.Integer> survivalSet
      This stores the rules that result in an alive cell staying alive. Default is Conway's Game of Life.

  • Constructor Details

    • LifePanel

      public LifePanel​(int xSize, int ySize, int pixelSize, java.awt.Color gridColor, java.awt.Color pixelColor, java.lang.String initialLoad)
      This unique constructor creates a LifePanel object. Its arguments' values will be dependent on user input. Only one specific type of LifePanel object can exist, which explains why there is only one constructor.
      Parameters:
      xSize - The number of columns in the array.
      ySize - The number of rows in the array.
      pixelSize - The size that each cell will be when displayed graphically. Influences xSize and ySize.
      gridColor - The default colour of the grid (used American spelling as the class is Color).
      pixelColor - The default colour of a cell. Can not be changed due to the existence of the heatmap.
      initialLoad - The initial state to start the automaton with. The user selects a save to start with using SizePopup.java, and the save file's name passed from it is used for initialLoad. If no save is chosen, it is an empty string.

  • Method Details

    • paintComponent

      public void paintComponent​(java.awt.Graphics g)
      Handles the drawing of the graphics of live pixels.
      Overrides:
      paintComponent in class javax.swing.JComponent
      Parameters:
      g - The Graphics object used to draw onto the screen. Arbitrarily named.

    • displayPixels

      private void displayPixels​(java.awt.Graphics g)
      This method iterates through the current 2D array of cells and displays them on the life panel.
      Parameters:
      g - The Graphics object used to draw onto the screen. Arbitrarily named.

    • gridCreator

      private void gridCreator​(java.awt.Graphics g)
      This flexible method creates a grid based on the number of cells and the size of cell graphics to be used.
      Parameters:
      g - The Graphics object used to draw onto the screen. Arbitrarily named.

    • randomSpawn

      private void randomSpawn()
      This method handles the random spawning of a start state. It sets cells in the automaton to age = 0, and some will randomly be state 1, and the rest are randomly state 0. With a 30% chance, a lot of cells that are made active will immediately die to overpopulation (default rules are Conway's Game of Life). This results in consistently "appropriate" starting states using this random initialisation.

    • nextGeneration

      void nextGeneration()
      This method applies rules and creates the next generation's life array (postLifeArray). First, check live cells against survival rules - if one applies, then the live cell will stay alive. Second, check dead cells against birth rules - if one applies, then the dead cell becomes alive. If no rules apply, then a live cell dies and a dead cell remains dead. This forms all possible rulesets of lifelike cellular automata.

    • check

      private int check​(int x, int y)
      This method checks the neighbour count of a given cell. It can be used with grid wrapping enabled or with it disabled. This method is effectively the heart of the simulation - so it must be as efficient as possible.
      Parameters:
      x - The x-coordinate of the cell to check.
      y - The y-coordinate of the cell to check.
      Returns:
      The number of neighbours that the cell at (x, y) has.

    • copyLifeArray

      private void copyLifeArray()
      This method copies the computed life array of the previous generation into the current generation's array that is displayed graphically. That is, postLifeArray is not displayed, but it is computed based on lifeArray. lifeArray is copied FROM postLifeArray, displayed to the screen, and used to generate the next postLifeArray. The new value for postLifeArray is then copied again to lifeArray for display, and so on.

    • emptyAutomaton

      void emptyAutomaton()
      This method sets all cell states to 0, in all known generations. The ages of all cells are also reset.

    • saveFile

      public void saveFile()
      This method saves the current state of the automaton (without its ruleset) to an external text file.

    • loadFile

      public void loadFile()
      This method loads a saved file, and sets the program to begin simulation from the loaded state. Makes use of the public static string saveToLoad to decide what filename to load.
      See Also:
      saveToLoad

    • mouseClicked

      public void mouseClicked​(java.awt.event.MouseEvent e)
      Used for drawing stamps. If the mouse is moved after clicking, stamps will not be used, allowing the user to draw a smooth line of live cells. That is, if the user clicks and drags, they will draw a smooth line of live cells instead of a line of clumped-up stamps.
      Specified by:
      mouseClicked in interface java.awt.event.MouseListener

      Specified by:

    • actionPerformed

      public void actionPerformed​(java.awt.event.ActionEvent e)
      Determines what should be done every time the program is updated, usually by timer generating an interrupt. Many of these flags and values are static, belonging to LifePanel. It makes little sense to initialise an object of LifePanel. Instead, the class is controlled statically. Every time the automaton updates (determined by the timer or by singleStepFlag), 5 statements are checked. 1: If the user wants to save. 2: If the user wants to load. 3: If the user wants to clear the automaton. 4: If the user wants to randomly generate a state. 5: If the simulation is currently not paused, create the next generation.
      Specified by:
      actionPerformed in interface java.awt.event.ActionListener
      Parameters:
      e - The action event that caused the program to update. This is usually caused by the timer generating an interrupt rhythmically, but can be triggered by other things.

    • stampPattern

      private void stampPattern​(int x, int y)
      Stamps predefined patterns onto the screen. This method is located at the bottom of the code as it is effectively just a database for patterns. This method draws pre-defined patterns onto the LifePanel, such as gliders. The data for what each pattern looks like is directly stored in lines of code (in methods beneath this one). Adding more patterns means adding more cases to this switch statement, and adding new buttons to the UI to call those switch cases. Creating a new case involves creating a new helper method that draws a specific pattern, and calling that method in the relevant switch. This makes the method flexible and well-expandable.
      Parameters:
      x - The mouse pointer's current x-coordinate.
      y - The mouse pointer's current y-coordinate.

    • stampGlider

      private void stampGlider​(int x, int y, int mirrorX, int mirrorY)
      A helper method to stampPattern that draws a glider pattern to the screen. If both mirrorX and mirrorY are disabled (i.e. both have the value 1), a glider that moves diagonally up-left will be drawn. If mirrorX is -1, the glider is flipped horizontally. If mirrorY is -1, the glider is flipped vertically. This means that four different orientations of glider can be drawn.
      Parameters:
      x - x-coordinate to draw the glider at.
      y - y-coordinate to draw the glider at.
      mirrorX - If this is -1, flip the glider horizontally. Either -1 or 1.
      mirrorY - If this is -1, flip the glider vertically. Either -1 or 1.
      See Also:
      stampPattern(int,int)

    • stampLWSS

      private void stampLWSS​(int x, int y, int mirrorX)
      A helper method to stampPattern that draws an LWSS pattern to the screen. If mirrorX is disabled (i.e. it has the value 1), then the LWSS will move left-to-right. If the pattern is mirrored in the x-axis, the LWSS will move right-to-left.
      Parameters:
      x - x-coordinate to draw the LWSS at.
      y - y-coordinate to draw the LWSS at.
      mirrorX - If this is -1, flip the LWSS horizontally. Either -1 or 1.
      See Also:
      stampPattern(int,int)

    • stampMWSS

      private void stampMWSS​(int x, int y, int mirrorX)
      A helper method to stampPattern that draws an MWSS pattern to the screen. If mirrorX is disabled (i.e. it has the value 1), then the MWSS will move left-to-right. If the pattern is mirrored in the x-axis, the MWSS will move right-to-left.
      Parameters:
      x - x-coordinate to draw the MWSS at.
      y - y-coordinate to draw the MWSS at.
      mirrorX - If this is -1, flip the MWSS horizontally. Either -1 or 1.
      See Also:
      stampPattern(int,int)

    • stampHWSS

      private void stampHWSS​(int x, int y, int mirrorX)
      A helper method to stampPattern that draws an HWSS pattern to the screen. If mirrorX is disabled (i.e. it has the value 1), then the HWSS will move left-to-right. If the pattern is mirrored in the x-axis, the HWSS will move right-to-left.
      Parameters:
      x - x-coordinate to draw the HWSS at.
      y - y-coordinate to draw the HWSS at.
      mirrorX - If this is -1, flip the HWSS horizontally. Either -1 or 1.
      See Also:
      stampPattern(int,int)

    • stampPulsar

      private void stampPulsar​(int x, int y)
      A helper method to stampPattern that draws a pulsar pattern to the screen. A pulsar is a 3-period oscillator.
      Parameters:
      x - x-coordinate to draw the pulsar at.
      y - y-coordinate to draw the pulsar at.
      See Also:
      stampPattern(int,int)

    • stampPentadecathlon

      private void stampPentadecathlon​(int x, int y)
      A helper method to stampPattern that draws a pentadecathlon pattern to the screen. A pentadecathlon is a 15-period oscillator.
      Parameters:
      x - x-coordinate to draw the pentadecathlon at.
      y - y-coordinate to draw the pentadecathlon at.
      See Also:
      stampPattern(int,int)

    • stampTumbler

      private void stampTumbler​(int x, int y)
      A helper method to stampPattern that draws a tumbler pattern to the screen. A tumbler is a 14-period oscillator.
      Parameters:
      x - x-coordinate to draw the tumbler at.
      y - y-coordinate to draw the tumbler at.
      See Also:
      stampPattern(int,int)

    • stampFigureEight

      private void stampFigureEight​(int x, int y)
      A helper method to stampPattern that draws a figure eight pattern to the screen. A figure eight is an 8-period oscillator.
      Parameters:
      x - x-coordinate to draw the figure eight at.
      y - y-coordinate to draw the figure eight at.
      See Also:
      stampPattern(int,int)

    • stampPhoenix

      private void stampPhoenix​(int x, int y)
      A helper method to stampPattern that draws a phoenix pattern to the screen. The phoenix is a special type of period-2 oscillator.
      Parameters:
      x - x-coordinate to draw the figure eight at.
      y - y-coordinate to draw the figure eight at.
      See Also:
      stampPattern(int,int)
